School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China Graphical abstract Transesterification of symmetrical organic carbonates with alcohols to access the unsymmetrical ones is a highly attractive strategy for upgrading biomass-derived alcohols. Robust, facile-prepared, and cost-effective catalytic materials remain highly desirable for this route. Herein, we designed several Zn-based catalysts (denoted as Zn@C-T, where T represented the pyrolysis temperature) by the pyrolysis of Zn-based coordination polymer at different temperatures. Very interestingly, the prepared Zn@C-900 could efficiently catalyze the transesterification of diethyl carbonate (DEC) with various biomass-derived alcohols to synthesize the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates with high yields (>95 %), resulting from the atomically dispersed ZnNx sites on the N-doped carbon. Notably, good catalytic activity could be obtained at a low temperature of 80 °C, representing the major breakthrough. Detailed investigations indicated that the excellent performance of Zn@C-900 originated mainly from the synergistic effect of Zn (to activate DEC) and N (to activate the alcohols) in the ZnNx sites. This work provided a promising efficient catalyst for low-temperature production of unsymmetrical organic carbonates via transesterification of DEC. Keywords Single-atom catalyst Biomass-derived alcohols Unsymmetrical organic carbonates Transesterification Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Organic carbonates are an important class of valuable chemicals extensively applied as fuel additives, polar aprotic solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, versatile intermediates for synthesizing agricultural chemicals, pharmaceuticals and lubricants, and important monomers for organic glass [1–3]. Generally, unsymmetrical organic carbonates show better performance in practical applications than the symmetrical ones [4]. Thereby, development of efficient catalytic systems for synthesizing unsymmetrical organic carbonates has gained much attention. Traditionally, toxic reagents, e.g., phosgene, dimethyl sulfate, and pyridine, were indispensable for the synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates [5]. With the rapid development of green chemistry, several simpler and more eco-friendly strategies have been proposed, including the coupling of alcohols, CO2, and alkyl halides [6], the direct reaction of CO2 and alcohols [7], and transesterification of symmetrical organic carbonates with alcohols. Among these developed strategies, transesterification of symmetrical organic carbonates with alcohols is a very attractive approach because this approach not only avoids the use of halogenated compounds but also possesses much higher activity and product selectivity than the route of direct reaction between CO2 and alcohols. Notably, with the significant development of biorefineries, diverse alcohols can be generated from transformation of renewable biomass. These features afford transesterification of symmetrical organic carbonates with alcohols being a cost-effective and environment-friendly approach to produce unsymmetrical organic carbonates. Various catalysts have been developed for the synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates via transesterification of symmetrical organic carbonates (e.g., diethyl carbonate, and dimethyl carbonate) with alcohols. For example, CsF/α-Al2O3 was employed as a heterogeneous basic catalyst for the production of unsymmetrical organic carbonates by the transesterification of diethyl carbonate (DEC) at 120 °C [8]. Several MgO-based catalysts were developed to catalyze the transesterification of DEC at the reaction temperature of 120–130 °C [9]. Moreover, Mg/La metal oxide [10], homogeneous TBD (1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene) [11], and MCM-41-TBD could also be used as basic catalysts for the transesterification of DEC [12]. Besides these basic catalysts, Zn-based metal–organic framework (MOF) [13] and organotin-oxomolybdate coordinated polymer [14] as bifunctional catalysts could efficiently catalyze the production of unsymmetrical organic carbonates via the transesterification of DEC. In spite of these achievements, most of the developed catalysts were still limited by some drawbacks, including harsh reaction temperatures (>120 °C), long reaction time (>10 h), high usage of metal elements, and unsatisfied stability (especially for the basic catalysts), etc. Undoubtedly, from the practical perspective, robust, heterogeneous, and stable catalysts are still highly desirable for the synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates via transesterification of DEC with different alcohols under mild conditions. For transesterification of DEC and alcohols, most of the developed metal-based catalysts were heterogeneous. The main challenge of these heterogeneous catalysts was the partial embedding of catalytically active sites in the bulk body, resulting in the difficulty on the interaction between these active sites and reactants as well as their insufficient utilization. Generally, the accessibility of catalytically active sites in heterogeneous catalysts could be significantly enhanced by constructing advanced structures, such as hierarchically porous structures, nanosheets, and atomic dispersion of catalytic sites [15–19]. Especially, the catalysts with atomically dispersed active sites, called as single-atom catalysts (SACs), have drawn significant interest in catalysis community owing to the inherent merits, i.e., highly dense distribution of active sites, tunable electronic structures, high atomic utilization efficiency, and efficient mass transfer [20–25]. These merits afforded SACs being the ideal choice for diverse catalytic transformations [26–28]. Based on the previously reported results, transesterification of DEC and alcohols could be catalyzed by acidic catalysts. In SACs, the atomic metal species could potentially play the role of acidic sites to promote the transesterification. Thus, there was a great opportunity that transesterification of DEC and alcohols could be efficiently and mildly promoted by constructing innovative SACs. Encouraged by the merits of SACs, in this work, we prepared atomic Zn catalytic materials (denoted as Zn@C-T, where T represented the pyrolysis temperature) by pyrolyzing Zn-based coordination polymer formed from ZnCl2 and 4,4′-bipyridine. It was observed that the synthesized Zn@C-900 as a single-atom catalyst showed outstanding catalytic activity on the production of unsymmetrical organic carbonates by the transesterification of DEC and various biomass-derived alcohols. Especially, Zn@C-900 still exhibited good performance for the reaction at a low temperature of 80 °C, which represented a major breakthrough for the acid-catalyzed transesterification of DEC. To the best of our knowledge, this was the first time to achieve low-temperature (<100 °C) transesterification of DEC and alcohols to access unsymmetrical organic carbonates over SACs. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Ethanol (99.8 %), tetradecane (99 %), veratryl alcohol (98 %), 4,4′-bipyridine (98 %), diethyl carbonate (99 %), 1-hexanol (98 %), 2-ethylhexanol (>99 %), 2-ethyl-1-butanol (98 %), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (≥98 %), menthol (99 %), benzyl alcohol (≥99 %), and cyclohexanol (≥98.5 %) were obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Zinc chloride (ZnCl2, ≥98 %) was purchased from Guangzhou Chemical Reagent Factory. Chitosan (91.8 %, 310CPS) was provided by Shandong Aokang Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Argon (99.999 %) were obtained from Generally Yuejia Gas Co., Ltd. Dimethicone (100 cst) was purchased from Guangzhou Kerong Biological Co., Ltd. 2.2 Construction of Zn@C-T catalysts To prepare Zn@C-T, the Zn-based coordination polymer was initially synthesized. In a typical synthetic route, 4,4′-bipyridine (40 mmol) and ZnCl2 (30 mmol) were dissolved in 300 mL ethanol. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Finally, the desired coordination polymer was obtained by centrifugation, washed by ethanol, and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, the obtained Zn-based coordination polymer was pyrolyzed in a furnace for 3 h at 900 °C (or 600, 700, 800, and 1000 °C) at the heating rate of 5 °C/min under Ar gas flow, and then naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain the Zn@C-T, in which T represented the treatment temperature. For comparison, N-doped carbon material or ZnO were obtained at 900 °C using chitosan or ZnCl2 as the raw material, respectively. Other conditions were the same as the route of preparing Zn@C-T. 2.3 Catalysts characterization Scanning electron microscope (SEM) measurements were conducted on the Quattro S instrument. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with JEM-F200. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field STEM (HAADF-STEM) tests were conducted on Titan Cubed Themis G2300 300kv. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed on an X-ray diffractometer (MiniFlex II, Rigaku) operated at Cu Kα radiation with a scanning rate of 10° min−1 in the range of 5–80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected on an ESCAL Lab 220i-XL spectrometer with Al Kα as the excitation source and operated at 15 kV and 20 mA. The content of Zn in the prepared catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) (Thermo Fisher iCAP 7400). N2 adsorption–desorption examinations were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP 2046 (USA) surface area analyzer at 77.35 K. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were carried out at the 4B9A beamline at Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF), China. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were obtained using the Athena software package. Temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) was conducted on the BELCAT-A instrument, and the detailed route for CO2-TPD was described as follows. Initially, after adding the sample (100 mg) to one quartz instrument, the temperature was increased from room temperature to 300 °C under a flow of He (30 mL/min). The temperature was kept at 300 °C for 1h and then decreased to 50 °C. Then, 10 % CO2 (30–50 mL/min) was introduced into the quartz instrument at 50 °C for 1h to ensure the adsorption saturation of CO2. After the physically adsorbed CO2 was removed by He (30 mL/min), the temperature was increased from 50 to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under He atmosphere, and the outgoing gas was detected by TCD. Finally, the basicity could be obtained based on the CO2-TPD results. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was conducted on the BELCAT-A instrument, and the detailed route for NH3-TPD was described as follows. Initially, after adding the sample (100 mg) to one quartz instrument, the temperature was increased from room temperature to 300 °C under a flow of He (30 mL/min). The temperature was kept at 300 °C for 1 h and then decreased to 50 °C. Then, 10 % NH3/He mixture (30–50 mL/min) was introduced into the quartz instrument at 50 °C for 1 h to ensure the adsorption saturation of NH3. After the physically adsorbed NH3 was removed by He (30 mL/min), the temperature was increased from 50 to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under He atmosphere, and the outgoing gas was detected by TCD. Finally, the acidity could be obtained based on the NH3-TPD results. 2.4 The process to conduct the transesterification All the reactions were conducted in a flask of 25 mL with a reflux condenser. In a typical experiment, the alcohol (2 mmol), DEC (33 mmol, 4 mL), and the catalyst with desired amounts were added into the flask, which was then placed into an oil bath with a desired constant temperature. After the reaction was performed for the desired time, the reaction was stopped by taking the flask out of the oil bath. Finally, the unreacted alcohol and the generated products were analyzed by a gas chromatography (GC, Shimadzu 2010 Pro, using tetradecane as the internal standard) equipped with a flame-ionized detector and an RB-5 capillary column (0.25 mm in diameter and 30 m in length), and the products were also confirmed by GC–MS (Shimadzu QP 2010PLUS). 2.5 Reusability of the Zn@C-900 In the experiments to determine the reusability, the spent Zn@C-900 was separated via centrifugation and washed with ethanol (3 × 5 mL) to remove the unconverted reactant and the product. After being dried at 80 °C under vacuum for 3 h, the recovered Zn@C-900 was directly reused in the next catalytic cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication and characterization of the Zn@C-T materials The desired Zn@C-T catalysts were fabricated by the pyrolysis of Zn-based coordination polymer, and the detailed route was described in the experimental section. Initially, the prepared Zn-based coordination polymer was characterized by SEM and TEM techniques (Fig. S1). No uniform morphology was observed in the SEM image of synthesized Zn-based coordination polymer (Fig. S1a). Nonetheless, there were plenty of pores on the Zn-based coordination polymer based on the TEM result (Fig. S1b). Besides, elemental mapping images indicated that Zn, C and N elements in the fabricated Zn-based coordination polymer were distributed uniformly (Fig. S1d). Moreover, the thermal decomposition of the Zn-based coordination polymer was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in Fig. S2, the weight of the Zn-based coordination polymer remained almost constant before 400 °C. The Zn-based coordination polymer rapidly decomposed from 400 to 600 °C, resulting from the decomposition of the organic component (4,4′-bipyridine). The weight loss (8.62 wt%) after 600 °C predominantly originated from the volatilization of Zn based on the elemental contents in the prepared materials obtained at different pyrolysis temperatures (Table S1). These results confirmed the feasibility of fabricating the desired catalytic materials by the pyrolysis of the Zn-based coordination polymer at different temperatures. The morphology and properties of the prepared Zn@C-T materials were examined by several typical techniques. The SEM images indicated that the five obtained materials, i.e., Zn@C-600, Zn@C-700, Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000, showed no uniform morphology (Fig. 1 , and S3-S6). Nevertheless, small particles on the material surface were observed when the materials (e.g., Zn@C-600, and Zn@C-700) were prepared at lower temperatures (Fig. S3a and S4a), while these particles disappeared at the higher fabricated temperatures (Fig. 1a, S5a, and S6a). As characterized by TEM, no obvious agglomeration of Zn particles could be found in the Zn@C-700 (Fig. S4b-c), Zn@C-800 (Fig. S5b-c), Zn@C-900 (Fig. 1b-c), and Zn@C-1000 (Fig. S6b-c). Especially, the HAADF-STEM analysis revealed that the Zn species were atomically dispersed in Zn@C-900 (Fig. 1d), indicating the successful synthesis of Zn single atoms (bright white dots, highlighted by red circles) [29]. In contrast, characteristic lattice fringes for ZnO could be clearly observed at the interplanar distance of 0.24 nm for (101) plane and 0.28 nm for (100) plane in the TEM image of Zn@C-600 (Fig. S3b-c), implying the existence of ZnO particles [30]. Moreover, as shown in these TEM images, all these five materials possessed a large number of honeycomb pores. Elemental mapping images demonstrated the uniform distribution of Zn, O, and N elements in the five catalytic materials (Fig. 1e-f, S3d-e, S4d-e, S5d-e, and S6d-e). In addition, as determined by ICP-OES, the content of Zn in the five catalysts decreased with the increase of the pyrolysis temperature (Table S1) owing to the evaporation of Zn at the temperature of above 600 °C. The XRD patterns of Zn@C-T catalysts with different Zn contents were shown in Fig. 2 a. All samples exhibited two broad peaks at around 26 and 44°, which was ascribed to (002) and (101) planes of graphitic carbon [31,32]. More importantly, there was no extra diffractions of Zn species in the XRD patterns, suggesting that the introduced Zn species should be highly dispersed on the surface of the carbon carrier. Additionally, Zn@C-900 showed very similar XRD pattern with the N-doped carbon material prepared from the pyrolysis of chitosan at 900 °C (Fig. S7), further implying the high dispersion of Zn species in Zn@C-T. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of Zn@C-T (Fig. 2b) showed the mode of type I (for Zn@C-600) or type IV (Fig. S8-12) (for Zn@C-700, Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000), revealing the presence of abundant mesopores in the synthesized five materials. Meanwhile, the BET surface area of the prepared Zn@C-T increased with the increase of pyrolysis temperature from 600 to 900 °C, and then decreased when the pyrolysis temperature was further increased to 1000 °C (Table S2). Besides, the pore size showed no obvious difference (Table S2). The fine structure of Zn@C-T was further characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The full XPS spectra (Figs. S13a, S14a, S15a, S16a, S17a) showed the coexistence of Zn, N, O, and C in the five catalysts, suggesting that Zn and N were successfully doped. High-resolution XPS spectra of Zn 2p showed that there were two peaks at ca. 1022 (for Zn 2p3/2) and 1045 eV (for Zn 2p1/2), implying that Zn was in an ionic state (Fig. 3 a) [33]. The binding energy of Zn 2p for the five catalytic materials slightly decreased as the following tendency: Zn@C-600 > Zn@C-700 > Zn@C-800 > Zn@C-900 ≈ Zn@C-1000, implying that the valence of Zn species decreased gradually (Fig. S18). Among these materials, Zn@C-600 showed the close binding energy of Zn 2p with ZnO, suggesting the Zn species in Zn@C-600 were mainly ZnO, which was consistent with the results of HR-TEM (Fig. S3). The gradually decreased binding energies of Zn 2p in other four materials indicated that the valence of Zn species (Znδ+, 0 < δ < 2) in these materials became lower, indicating the interaction between Zn species and N species became stronger. Especially, Zn@C-900 and Zn@C-1000 showed the lowest binding energy of Zn 2p, probably owing to the formation of much more atomically dispersed ZnNx species [34]. Moreover, in the XPS spectra of N 1s (Fig. 3b), besides three characteristic N-species, i.e., pyridine-type N (398.0 eV), pyrrole-type N (399.5 eV), and graphitic-type N (401.2 eV) [35], a new peak located at 399.4 eV was observed in Zn@C-700, Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000, assigned to the N-species coordinated with the Zn sites [36]. The contents of the four N species in the five materials varied with the prepared temperatures, which significantly affected the formation of Zn-N4 sites. Importantly, the peak area for Zn-N species decreased as follows: Zn@C-900 > Zn@C-1000 > Zn@C-800 > Zn@C-700, suggesting that Zn@C-900 showed the highest content of Zn-N species. In contrast, there were no Zn-N species in Zn@C-600. The difference on the content of Zn-N species was the probable reason for their different catalytic activity, as discussed below. Besides, XPS spectra of C 1s indicated that there were three carbon species with the corresponding binding energies at 284.8, 285.9 and 288.3 eV (Fig. S16b), which attributed to sp2 CC in the framework, CN species, and OCO/quinone group groups, respectively [37]. For the XPS spectra of O 1s (Fig. S16c), only one peak at 531.9 eV was mainly attributed to hydroxyl COH or ether (531.8–532.1 eV), suggesting that there were many O-containing groups on the surface of the prepared catalysts [38]. Fourier-transformed (FT) k3 -weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra was collected to further reveal the fine structure of the prepared samples. FT-EXAFS spectra showed that there were two coordination peaks at ca. 1.53 (for Zn-O/Zn-N coordination peak) and ca. 2.91 Å (for Zn-Zn coordination peak) in the Zn@C-600 (Fig. S19). Based on the contents of Zn and N in Zn@C-600 (Table S1), most of the atoms coordinated with Zn should be O atoms rather than N atoms. Thus, deduced from the results of elemental content and FT-EXAFS spectra, Zn species in the Zn@C-600 mainly was ZnO, agreeing with the TEM result (Fig. S3). With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the peak Zn-Zn coordination peak gradually decreased and disappeared in the Zn@C-900 and Zn@C-1000 (Fig. 4 a and S19-S22), confirming that the ZnO would be transformed into atomically dispersed Zn species bonded by N or O. As shown in Fig. 3b, the content of Zn-Nx sites increased. Thus, we deduced that more N atoms were bonded with Zn atoms to form Zn-Nx sites at higher pyrolysis temperature. Zn K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) showed that the absorption edge of all the five fabricated samples was not consistent with ZnO and Zn foil, but the absorption threshold was more closed to that of ZnO (Fig. 4b and S19-S22), indicating the valence state of Zn species was between 0 and +2 (close to +2). Moreover, based on the results for Zn K-edge EXAFS (Fig. 4c and S19-S22), Zn@C-600 and Zn@C-700 showed very similar spectra with ZnO, implying that Zn-O was the major coordination in these two samples. In comparison, Zn@C-900 and Zn@C-1000 showed different spectra with ZnO, implying Zn-N coordination became the predominate one. Zn@C-900 and Zn@C-1000 exhibited a single intensity maximum around 3.90 Å−1 (Fig. 4c and S19-S23), corresponding to the first nearest neighbor shell of the coordination between Zn and N, while there was no Zn-Zn signal, confirming the isolated nature of the Zn atom in Zn@C-900 and Zn@C-1000. Besides, wavelet transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (WT-EXAFS) analysis revealed the coordination number of the Zn atom was calculated to be 3.8–4.3 (Fig. 4d, S19-S22, and Table S3). Especially, the coordination number decreased with the pyrolysis temperature: Zn@C-600 (4.3) > Zn@C-700 (4.2) > Zn@C-800 (4.1) > Zn@C-900 (4.0) > Zn@C-1000 (3.8). These results above confirmed the generation of well-defined in-plane ZnN4 sites in Zn@C-900 and Zn@C-1000, and the coordination environment of Zn could be well adjusted by the pyrolysis temperature of preparing the catalytic materials. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the Zn@C-T on transesterification of DEC The catalytic activity of the fabricated Zn@C-T catalysts was initially evaluated using the transesterification of DEC with 1-hexanol (an alcohol that could be synthesized from the conversion of glucose or bioethanol) as the model reaction (Table 1 ). It was observed that no reaction occurred in the absence of any catalyst (Table 1, entry 1). The reaction proceeded smoothly using Zn@C-T as the catalysts at a low temperature of 80 °C (Table 1, entries 2–6). To our delight, the yield of the desired unsymmetrical organic carbonate could reach 95 % and 93 % over Zn@C-900 (Table 1, entry 5) and Zn@C-1000 (Table 1, entry 6) as the catalysts, respectively. Especially, Zn@C-900 provided slightly higher product yield and selectivity than Zn@C-1000, suggesting that Zn@C-900 was the optimal catalyst. In comparison, ZnO (Fig. S24) prepared by the pyrolysis of ZnCl2 showed very poor catalytic performance for the reaction (Table 1, entry 7), implying that the properties of Zn species in Zn@C-900 were different with those in ZnO. Considering that the catalytic activity of Zn@C-900 may originate from the N sites (as the basic sites), N-doped carbon material was obtained by the pyrolysis of chitosan. Unfortunately, the yield of the desired product was only 7 % over this N-doped carbon material (Table 1, entry 8). Besides, Zn@C-1200 was constructed to ensure complete volatilization of Zn, and the Zn content in Zn@C-1200 was below 0.05 wt% based on the ICP-OES results. It was observed that the catalytic activity of Zn@C-1200 was very low (Table 1, entry 9). These results above confirmed that Zn species were indispensable. It is widely accepted that transesterification could be catalyzed by acidic or basic sites [39]. Therefore, we determined the acidity and basicity of all the prepared Zn@C-T materials. First, as determined by NH3-TPD, two peaks were observed (Fig. S25), corresponding to weak acidic sites (at the desorption temperature of around 127 °C), and strong acidic sites (at the desorption temperature of 300–400 °C). It was observed that Zn@C-600, Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000 possessed both types of acidic sites, while Zn@C-700 only had weak acidic sites. Besides, Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000 showed a higher desorption temperature than Zn@C-600 for the strong acidic sites (Fig. S25), implying the acid-strength in the Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000 was much higher. Although the total content of acidic sites in Zn@C-600 and Zn@C-700 was much larger (Table S4), their catalytic activity was unsatisfactory. The lower catalytic activity of Zn@C-700 was probably caused by the lack of strong acidic sites, indicating that the strong acidic sites were more efficient to promote the reaction. Although Zn@C-600 possessed the highest strong acidic sites (Table S4), its surface area was only 5.2 m2/g (Table S2), limiting the exposure of catalytically active sites and the mass transfer, which would significantly lower its catalytic activity. In comparison, Zn@C-900 possessed the highest content of strong acidic sites (Table S4) and relatively high surface area. Higher content of strong acidic sites was beneficial for activating the reactants, and the high surface area was favorable for the exposure of catalytic sites to interact with the reactants. These two parameters afforded Zn@C-900 possessing the highest catalytic activity. Second, the CO2-TPD results suggested that the basicity of the five Zn@C-T materials showed no significant difference on the total content of basic sites (Table S5). Nevertheless, Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000 had much higher desorption temperature than Zn@C-600 and Zn@C-700 (Fig. S26), suggesting that the strength for the basic sites on Zn@C-800, Zn@C-900, and Zn@C-1000 was higher than Zn@C-600 and Zn@C-700, which may be positively related with their catalytic activity. However, the N-doped carbon (Table 1, entry 8) with similar content and strength of basic sites (Fig. S26) showed low catalytic activity. These CO2-TPD results implied that the basic sites were probably not the dominated sites for the transesterification of DEC in our prepared materials. Third, as well-accepted, the defects of carbon-based materials could also be the catalytically active sites. Based on the results of Raman spectra (Fig. S27), the intensity ratio of D and G bands (ID /IG ) in the five catalytic materials decreased with the increase of the pyrolysis temperature from 600 to 1000 °C, indicating the decreased content of the defects in the corresponding catalysts with the increased pyrolysis temperature. However, the catalytic activity of these five catalysts increased with the decreased ID /IG , implying that the defects on the catalysts were not the decisive catalytically active sites in the prepared five catalysts. Additionally, the poor catalytic activity of ZnO (Table 1, entry 7) and the N-doped carbon material (Table 1, entry 8) implied that the signal Zn or N sites were not the actual catalytic sites. More importantly, the catalytic activity of the synthesized materials was proportional to the relative content of the Zn-Nx species (Table 1, and Fig. 3b). These results confirmed that the Zn-Nx species (atomically dispersed Zn sites) were indeed responsible for the high catalytic activity of Zn@C-900. Considering its best performance, Zn@C-900 was selected as the optimal catalyst to optimize the reaction conditions. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions Generally, the reaction temperature could significantly affect the catalytic efficiency, and thus we investigated the effect of reaction temperature on transesterification of DEC with 1-hexanol over Zn@C-900 (Fig. 5 a). As expected, the yield of the desired product increased with the increase of the reaction temperature from 50 to 80 °C, and there was no obvious change on the reaction results when the reaction temperature was further increased to 90 °C, indicating that 80 °C was the optimal temperature for our catalytic system. At 80 °C, the yield of the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonate could reach 95 %. Zn@C-900 still showed high catalytic activity at a such low temperature (80 °C), which was lower than previously reported results (Table S6) [8–10,12–14,40], verifying the superior of Zn@C-900 on the transesterification of DEC. Subsequently, the influence of the catalyst usage was determined (Fig. 5b). It was observed that the yield of the product increased with the increasing catalyst usage from 0 to 100 mg because there were more catalytically active sites with more catalyst usage. Thus, 100 mg would be an appropriate catalyst amount in our catalytic system. Moreover, the yield of the corresponding product continually increased with the prolonging reaction time from 0 to 6 h (Fig. 5c), and the maximum yield of 95 % could be obtained with a reaction time of 6 h. When the reaction time was prolonged to 8 h, the yield and selectivity of the unsymmetrical organic carbonate maintained at 95 % and 98 %, respectively. Finally, the recyclability of Zn@C-900 was examined. To our delight, Zn@C-900 can be recycled at least 4 times without significant loss of catalytic activity (Fig. 5d). The recovered Zn@C-900 was characterized by XRD (Fig. S28), and the results showed that there was no considerable change on the properties between the fresh Zn@C-900 and the recovered one. Meanwhile, SEM and TEM images (Fig. S29) indicated that the morphology of the recovered Zn@C-900 after four catalytic cycles remained unchanged in comparison with the fresh catalyst. Besides, as determined by ICP-OES technique, the Zn content in the recovered Zn@C-900 was ca. 1.25 wt%, which was very similar with that in the fresh Zn@C-900. Particularly, the EXAFS spectra (Fig. S30) showed that no obvious difference was found between the virgin and recovered Zn@C-900. These results above confirmed the excellent stability of Zn@C-900 for the reaction. In addition, we should point out that disubstituted carbonate was generated as the by-product in the reaction process although its amount was very low (<3 %). 3.4 Scope of biomass-derived alcohols Encouraged by its excellent performance on transesterification of DEC with 1-hexanol, Zn@C-900 was further employed to catalyze the transesterification of DEC with other biomass-derived alcohols, including aliphatic alcohols (i.e., 2-ethylbutanol, and 2-ethylhexanol, synthesized from bioethanol upgrading), alicyclic alcohols (i.e., tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol from the hydrogenation of furfural, cyclohexanol obtained from conversion of some lignin-based derivatives, and menthol extracted from some plants), and aromatic alcohols (i.e., benzyl alcohol and veratryl alcohol, potentially obtained from lignin conversion). It was observed that Zn@C-900 could convert various alcohols to the corresponding unsymmetrical carbonates at 80 °C (Table S7). From the viewpoint of practical applications, it would be more favorable to complete the reaction at relatively short reaction time under satisfactory reaction conditions. Thus, we modified the reaction temperature for different alcohols. To our delight, all the examined alcohols (Table 2 ) could be efficiently converted into the corresponding unsymmetrical carbonates with high selectivity (97–99 %) at the temperature of 80–130 °C. The reactivity of the examined alcohols decreased as follows: aliphatic alcohols > aromatic alcohols > alicyclic alcohols, which were mainly caused by the steric hindrance and electronic effects of the alcohols [14]. The lower reactivity of aromatic alcohols (Table 2, entries 6 and 7) than alkyl alcohols originated from the delocalization of electrons in the benzene ring, which reduced the nucleophilicity of the generated alkoxide ion and its interaction with the catalytic sites. In the case of alicyclic alcohols (Table 2, entries 3–5), their lowest reactivity was due to the steric hindrance of the ring. 3.5 Reaction mechanism As well-accepted, transesterification of DEC with alcohols could be carried out via the nucleophilic mechanism on basic catalysts [10,40]. However, as discussed above, the catalytically active sites in Zn@C-900 were the atomic ZnNx sites, in which the Zn atom acted as the Lewis acidic sites to activate the DEC, and the N atoms played the role of basic sites for activating the alcohols. The synergistic cooperation between these two sites resulted in the excellent activity of Zn@C-900 at 80 °C. Based on the experimental results and the reported knowledge, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed for the transesterification of DEC with various alcohols (Scheme 1 ). Initially, the Zn atom in the ZnNx site interacted with the O atom in the carbonyl group of DEC, thereby activating the carbonyl group. Simultaneously, the hydroxyl group in the alcohol was activated by the ZnNx site by the formation of hydrogen bonding between the H atom in the hydroxyl group and the N atom in the ZnNx site. Subsequently, the O atom in the activated hydroxyl group of the alcohol attacked the C atom in the carbonyl group of DEC to generate a six-link intermediate. Finally, the desired unsymmetrical organic carbonate could be generated from this intermediate by releasing the ethanol (EtOH) and the catalyst. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, robust Zn-based catalysts (Zn@C-T) were fabricated by pyrolysis of Zn-based coordination polymer. The prepared Zn@C-T could efficiently catalyze the transesterification of DEC with various biomass-derived alcohols to synthesize unsymmetrical organic carbonates. The catalytic performance of the prepared Zn@C-T was significantly affected by the pyrolysis temperature, and the catalyst Zn@C-900 with atomically dispersed Zn sites showed the highest catalytic activity for the transesterification. Various alcohols, including aliphatic alcohols, alicyclic alcohols, and aromatic alcohols, could be selectively converted into the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates, and the yields and selectivities were >95 % and 99 %, respectively. More importantly, Zn@C-900 could also show good catalytic activity at a low temperature of 80 °C. Systematic study revealed that both Zn and N were indispensable, and the atomic ZnNx sites were the catalytically active sites. The excellent performance of Zn@C-900 originated from the synergistic effect of Zn and N in the atomically dispersed ZnNx sites. We believe that the prepared Zn@C-900 could be potentially applied as one robust single atom catalytic material for the transesterification of DEC and biomass-derived alcohols to produce unsymmetrical organic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: Transesterification of symmetrical organic carbonates with alcohols to access the unsymmetrical ones is a highly attractive strategy for upgrading biomass-derived alcohols. Robust, facile-prepared, and cost-effective catalytic materials remain highly desirable for this route. Herein, we designed several Zn-based catalysts (denoted as Zn@C-T, where T represented the pyrolysis temperature) by the pyrolysis of Zn-based coordination polymer at different temperatures. Very interestingly, the prepared Zn@C-900 could efficiently catalyze the transesterification of diethyl carbonate (DEC) with various biomass-derived alcohols to synthesize the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates with high yields (>95 %), resulting from the atomically dispersed ZnNx sites on the N-doped carbon. Notably, good catalytic activity could be obtained at a low temperature of 80 °C, representing the major breakthrough. Detailed investigations indicated that the excellent performance of Zn@C-900 originated mainly from the synergistic effect of Zn (to activate DEC) and N (to activate the alcohols) in the ZnNx sites. This work provided a promising efficient catalyst for low-temperature production of unsymmetrical organic carbonates via transesterification of DEC.
